text: people who work for Amazon yeah who's
head of Cambridge we're near Cambridge
us we're about an hour north of London
and about sort of 50 kilometers north
northwest of Cambridge we're relatively
small councils about 185 thousand people
who live in the city generally sort of
low skilled manufacturing jobs a huge
migrant population we speak something
like 120 different languages in the city
and as a council we also have to be able
to deliver services to all of those guys
which is so what we're looking at really
is a change to the way that the city
operates so it's not just about the
council and the services we do it's
about the city as a whole and some of
our priorities the main one is really
around growth and regeneration that's
the key for us being able to achieve the
budget pressures and the cuts that the
UK government is putting on most
councils at the moment as part of that
we've been looking about smart cities
now in a lot of senses people talk about
smart cities and talk about putting lots
of sensors around the city collecting
lots of information but they don't
target that information so I'm being
constantly told about traffic sensors
that we could put up and we can monitor
cars and movement and traffic flows
Peters repeater has got the
second-fastest commuting times in the
country so we don't really need those
sensors where we're challenged is the
health economy and as I said the migrant
population getting them to get them into
work get them into good proper jobs not
just low-skilled labor manufacturing
jobs and there's a couple of definitions
on smart city that we've worked on with
the British Standards Institute so the
first one is the integration of physical
digital in human systems which I'll go
into our broken the presentation into
those three categories but then the ISO
definition really is about the last line
to provide better services and quality
of life to those in the city so what
you've really got then is the three
areas the physical the digital and the
human and where they overlap where all
three meet that's where you're truly
being a smart city
so looking at the physical ones then
infrastructure we've been working within
the UK there's a big government roll out
about everyone getting better broadband
the UK government defines super fast as
24 megabits per second so we've got a
whole program that runs across
Peterborough and the county of Cambridge
here to try and get 24 Meg to about
ninety six percent of the population but
for us that's just a starting point so
we've introduced a company called Giga
clear who do some of the more remote
areas so every village just outside of
Peterborough by August will have access
to one gigabit internet connections we
then put free city Wi-Fi across the
center of the city that's going to be
extended across at the majority of the
city over the next two years and then
finally is City fiber so in 2013 we
signed a deal with a company called City
fiber to again put a dark fiber network
throughout Peterborough so this is this
is the core network it's 92 kilometres
and six counts of sites including all
schools museums libraries hospitals and
then 65 is ambition is to roll it out to
every business and every resident in the
city so the moment we've got about 150
businesses also with gigabit connections
we've got about another 900 in the
pipeline who have requested the service
that's over a quarter of all businesses
in the city and then the next two to
three years will start rolling that out
to residents as well so really we're
going to be one of the best connected
cities in the UK moving on to people the
human side of things fibre to the future
is our digital inclusion program it's
about how not just you get peak access
to people it's about making them
understand what the Internet can do for
them how it can help them how it can
lead to better lives so it might be that
we go into an old people's home for
example and show them how to do online
shopping so they can have their food
delivered so they can carry on cooking
meals where they can't get to the shops
it might just be something as simple as
a comparison website so to make sure
they're getting the best value for
things they buy in and off the back of
that the council wants to move services
online we want to have channel shift to
that so it just underpins the
moving our ambitions the next two groups
are community groups that meet up
regularly with in Peterborough so deep
it is digital people in Peterborough and
that's your your freelancers your web
designers and then agile Peterborough is
your code as your developers they meet
up once a month they have some talks
people come in and deliver some sessions
generally have a couple of drinks but
what we want to do is account to is tap
into all of that knowledge so there's
about six hundred people that attend
these groups in the city so how has a
counselor do we use their skills to help
us deliver better services and what
we've done is we've brought them both
together under the banner rope open city
so this is where we push challenges too
so where we've got issues in the council
where we've got data that we don't
understand or can't interpret we send
out to these guys and say can you make
sense of it what can you deliver back to
us so a very basic the very first basic
thing we did with them was an
interactive screen that was going in the
square we were looking at going out
purchasing the screen the council go and
what we're going to put on it who's
going to maintain it who's going to
update it and we turn around to these
and said would you do it for us would
you do it as a challenge they said
absolutely we did two 24-hour hackathons
and in July the screen will go live so
all the information on it has been put
on it by the residents it's been
maintained by the residents been looked
after by the residents so it's bad
having that inclusion so then what we do
is we'll start pushing some of the other
challenges out to them as well so when I
get into the weather stations the
information we gather from that will
also go to these guys so on that side of
things then on data which is the Digital
side of things data share is a program
that we're working on with the
government which is around the counts
will be an open and transparent so we
have to publish all our information of
where we spend our money where all our
services are where our properties are
how much we all learn if we own over a
certain amount and the council it's all
open data the government wants us to
publish we were then fortunate enough
for a couple of years ago to win three
million pounds from the government
as a future city demonstrator this was
about pulling together what a smart city
should be what it should do one of the
strands of it is living data and there
is a portal you can go on you can upload
information and just see how the how it
maps across Peterborough associate
socio-economic sort of things and then
the one that interests me most is is a
very simple premise working with a
company called science scope and it's
around weather stations so on the left
hand side as you're looking is probably
something we all did at school we cut
the top off a bottle we put a
measurement down the side we collected
rainwater we measured wind speed we'd
collected temperature all we're doing
really is taking that and bringing it
into 2015 so we've got 25 of these
weather stations going across this
across the city they're all going into
schools so 19 again into the primary
schools which is up to about 11 and then
six going into the senior schools which
is 12 to 18 so the primary aim of them
is to teach the kids about whether teach
them to understand the differences of
whether differences between rural
schools and inner-city schools and then
they're also going to have noise sensors
light sensors and various other things
attached to them but what we can now do
is publish all of that data so again
coming back to the Open City guys will
push this data to them and say okay well
can you map it against crime data or
hospital admission data or planning data
and those kind of things and is there
any correlation in that so can the
police change the way they they put
police on the street based on known what
weather patterns are going to come up
can hospitals change the way they give
appointments because we know there's
going to be a cold spell and we know
what that means that more people will
come through the accident and emergency
session so again we may not be
correlations but until we start
collecting that data and start analyzing
it it may take two or three years before
we've got enough good data that said the
primary aim is getting the kids
interested get them to understand the
environment and the changes that are
happening as a council we also have to
transform we have to change the way we
deliver services we haven't got the same
money that we used to have two three
four years ago
our budget shortfall this year was 25
million pounds which is a huge amount
for a council of our size so we've kind
of torn up the book on applications and
vendors the council's work with and
we've started to look at the private
sector so some of these names you'll
probably recognize Salesforce box amazon
akhtar is a single sign-on identity
management tool public stuff is a
reporting app you can put all your
potholes fly-tipping instance like that
exceed is an HR system but it's built on
the Salesforce platform transversal is
an FAQ system used by some of the
biggest companies in the UK Barclays
Bank John Lewis co-op bank so what we
want to do is start delivering the same
type of services that those guys deliver
to their customers to our residents so
Amazon were obviously using with a
partner with Amazon working with Chris
quite closely calling it a data center
is a bit bit much it's the server room
to be honest it's based at the Town Hall
most of the servers are at least six or
seven years old the air conditioning is
dying i got an email about two hours ago
saying can we turn off all non-essential
servers because the air-conditioning's
going because our air conditioning
doesn't like hot weather and instead of
doing a big refresh program redoing the
server room doing it up sorting it out
we started talking to amazon probably
about a year ago and we're now in the
process where the first 70 servers have
moved over we use various different
things we've got the direct connect
we've got one gig linked directly into
Amazon ec2 is where the servers are
going and the various other products and
the key thing for me really comes back
to to chris's point is amazon do so much
more than just host servers there's
hundreds of different services that they
provide and you really have to get into
it and look at what's out there what's
available and then on top of it you've
got all the partner tools as well so
where those issues of security you may
have to bring a third party tool in you
may have to look at encryption you may
have to look at something different but
you have to give the right level of risk
assessment to the right data
so if you're talking about potholes or
streetlights things like that that
information can fairly readily go into
the cloud if you're talking about
personal data health data you have to do
a lot more work you have to do a lot
more risk assessment and you may need to
put extra tools on top of what you're
doing but in the in the UK especially
it's not something that stops you from
doing it and then coming back to some of
the other key bits around big data some
of the services we're now looking at
moving to so the weather stations we're
going to start pushing all that data
into into lambda and start using that
and again as we grow and as we changed
as we change the way we run our services
what we'll find is that I think we'll
find is that what we started off with in
Amazon slowly shifts because we'll start
using more and more different tools and
as they keep coming up with more more
tools every year we'll start tapping
into those so again the machine learning
the predictive analysis how can we use
that in social care how can we
understand when something's going to
happen in social care before it actually
happens how do we stop some of the the
child abuse cases Peterborough's had a
very big child abuse case recently and
and we believe with predictive analysis
we could have seen that and stopped it
from happening we had a school boy
murdered at about 10 years ago in the
city we want to know when things are
looking bad we want to be able to
understand them and then step in and act
before it happens so to do that
basically the council's also then how to
transform so this this really should
look like a funnel so what we want to do
is capture everything towards the top so
if you can read it 2-0 at the top is
there is everything is going to be
online you're the website eforms your
customer accounts your own login tier 1
then becomes the call center the first
layer in the call center the more we can
capture there the better the more it
stops that coming through to the more
expensive tears tier 2 is kind of now at
a skilled call center level so within
our call center of the council we will
have social workers will have lawyers
will have planners will have all the
various services and then at tier 3 will
retain the specialist
so safeguarding children a few others
will stay at that point but effectively
if you looked at it like this tr.0 is
the cheapest they're here to serve
someone tier 3 is the most expensive so
the more you capture at the top the
cheaper is for the council to run that
and that allows us to spend more time
with those that actually need it so then
the technology sitting over the top of
that the digital services have as i said
is going to be the website it's the FAQ
system it's the customer login so
they've got their own account all of our
reforms are going into a single page you
don't have to search the web site
anymore and all of the tools we use our
design to be implemented or integrated
with Salesforce so behind it we've got
the Salesforce CRM system probably one
of the first councils in the UK to move
to Salesforce but for me it was a
no-brainer based on where we were going
to go as a council what we're then
looking at doing behind that layer is
rebuilding all the other those
applications that we've had for years
and years from the same vendors and
local authorities so on the force com
platform we're rebuilding housing
applications regulatory services
Children's Services adult social care
and building control and planning apps
and again they're all force calm they
integrate with Salesforce they'll
integrate with the front end there will
be some legacy stuff we're not going to
be able to get rid of everything in the
next two years but the plan is to keep
the legacy as small as possible with a
plan that it does eventually disappear
off the estate so what does that really
do it what it means is for the first
time we've got a completely integrated
council we've broken down all of the
silos the different data sets so if not
only have we got a front to back fully
integrated system because we would buy
in the right application we've actually
now got a left to right view of all the
residents as well so to give you an
example traditionally if we had three
complaints one in children services one
in housing one in regulatory services we
would send one officer individually to
each of those that all deal with it
individually what we want to know is
which is the underlying issue can we
just send one officer to the housing
issue
you've sought the housing issue the
other two take care of themselves we've
got no sort of visualization of that the
moment because we work in silos so what
we're going to have is a performance
team that sits behind that they're going
to be pulling all that data out there
going to be analyzing it seeing where
we're spending our money matching it
with the new HR information which is now
real time for the first time and also
our finance system data so how is
Children's Services affected by staff
sickness or costs and things like that
and it just gives us a much much better
view of all of our residents which
allows us to serve the ones that need
the help much much better than we
currently can so lastly we've got some
other projects that we're looking at
doing at the moment as well so we talked
about the city fiber network we're now
moving that into Phase two so we're
going to be putting the CCTV cameras the
information traffic systems and
real-time passenger information systems
on that and that's effectively another
210 access points across the city which
can then be used for the data points and
everything else as well open plus is
something we will looking at in the UK
most councils are close in their
libraries because we can't afford to run
them anymore we're opening our libraries
for longer using open + technology what
it means is that just unmanned so you
have to have an access card to get in
the library all the books have got a
RFID tags in the back so it's basically
a self-serve library and then smart
street lighting power over ethernet
lighting gives you basically complete
control of your lighting system and then
the Internet of Things towards
healthcare healthcare is our biggest
problem so we're working with a number
of local companies around how we can put
sensors into people's homes so you can
find out if they've got up in the middle
of the night gone to the bathroom and
not return to the bedroom that will send
an alert to a social worker who can go
and check they haven't fallen in the
bathroom you can put sensors on medicine
cabinets on doors you can put swipe
cards so you can see who's entered the
building who's left the building are
they up and about that allows you to
instead of sitting there on a monday and
saying i'm going to see these ten people
you can see those who flagged an alert
to you the ones who really need your
help
and it gives the little bit of
empowerment back to those residents to
to stay in their own homes for longer
and stay out of Social Care so hopefully
that's a bit of a rattle through what
we're going through in Peterborough at
the moment there's lots on it's a huge
challenge I think my beard was gray
about a year ago but it's slowly going
but thank you all for listening and hope
you found it useful
